climbs.name: Aqualung
climbs.fa: Steve Mackay and Alan Vick, January 1973

content.description: A decent 2nd pitch to Frustration, Pass Time, etc. From the bolted anchor head right on the ledge to two flake blocks, climb them then to a short finger crack, stay right of a tree and head up and left to a bolted anchor. Two raps to the ground or rap Insomnia with 70m on the other side.
content.protection: Some finger size pieces.
content.location: Right side of ledge that Frustration etc ends on.

climbs.name: Winter Solstice
climbs.fa: Hamilton Collins & Greg Rzonka, December 21, 1985

content.description:
Thin and continuous for much of the upper half, this challenging face route is best done when conditions are cold and crisp to ensure success. Although reasonably well protected for much of it's length the stretch going to the last bolt is a good 20 feet between bolts, so heads-up!

Start up a thin flake system, pass a black knob, and work up left and then back right to reach the 3rd bolt and the start of the difficulties. Move slightly right and up on tiny edges/friction to reach the 4th bolt and then continue up gradually more featured face to the top.

Originally rated 5.11a this climb has gotten more difficult over time as most of the tiny edges used on the first ascent have broken off and the rock has become polished from traffic.
content.protection: 5 bolts, 2 bolt anchor (100' rap)
content.location:
Between

Bacon Bits (aka Razor Games)

and

Arcy Farcy

.

climbs.name: When You're Sap
climbs.fa: Bob and Yvonne Gaines, July 1988.

content.description: From the Tree on Frustration Ledge stem with the tree until you have to commit to the wall, 15 feet up, then a easy mantle move to the first bolt. Crunchy flakes to a second bolt. Straight up from there or finish left.
content.protection: 2 bolts, small cam up high.
content.location: Tree on Frustration Ledge, can't miss it.

climbs.name: Walk the Plank
climbs.fa: FA: Bob and Yvonne Gaines - 1987  FFA: Darrell Hensel - 1989

content.description:
Start on the left leaning flake (5.7) just left of the

Captain Hook

start. Continue in the shallow flakes (4" piece) to their end, and make a few moves (10b) to obtain the upper crack. Gear protects the crack until it thins down into seams. Two bolts protect climbing up the seams (12a). A small cam may be placed between the bolts. End at the Pirate belay.
content.protection: Bolts, thin gear up to one 4" piece.  Small cams useful.

climbs.name: Sword of Damocles
climbs.fa: J. Gosling and Larry Harrell, March 1968

content.description: This is the third crack to the right of the Captain Hook chimney.  The "sword" (loose flake in the crack) that gave the route its name is gone.  It is a mediocre crack and chimney route.  To descend, walk right to a tree and rappel 160' to the ground.
content.protection: standard rack

climbs.name: Swashbuckler
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Mike Confer, June 1987.

content.description: From The Pirate ledge go right on some tricky face moves, leads to a arete and then to a horizontal crack. Climb crack to top of buttress.
content.protection: cams to 3"

climbs.name: The Pirate
climbs.fa: Pat Callis & Larry Reynolds, June 1967, FFA: Tony Yaniro, 1978

content.description:
P1) A combination of tip jams and face moves down low gain the security of a knob, conveniently located next to the crack, above which the difficulty eases (5.11) and the crack opens up to accept better locks. Near the top of the first pitch traverse slightly right to a bolted belay; thin fingers or a lack of feeling in your fingers is a plus on this pitch.

P2) Back left into the crack and up the moderate (5.9) crack to the top. It's also possible to do this all in one pitch if so inclined. Belay atop Double Exposure and then descend the backside.

The first pitch is often popular to practice clean aid (C2) and is often attempted on toprope by climbing

The Buccaneer

to access the anchors.
content.protection: Gear to 2 inches (include many thin nuts), bolted anchors
content.location:
Just right of

Double Exposure

's sharp arete.

climbs.name: Pieces of Eight
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Mike Van Volkom, June 1987

content.description: Starts at P1 bolts for Pirate or Walk the Plank. Very much like the Sundike on Sunshine Wall. Step left at third bolt to Finish on Pirate or Double Exposure (recommended).
content.protection: Three bolts, one medium cam, one extra bolt if finishing on Double Exposure
content.location: Straight above Bolts for Walk the Plank.

climbs.name: Overexposed Variation
climbs.fa: Old School

content.description:
Interesting way to gain the Double Exposure Arete. Start on Insomnia but go right at the dangerous looking block. Traverse straight right to the third bolt of Double Exposure.

On TR I walked the dike to the arete but the true line is probably walking the sloping ramp a bit lower.

NO PRO!
content.protection: None out of the Insomnia Chimney. Stance for a drilling a bolt on the traverse, if someone is so inclined.

climbs.name: Pass Time
climbs.fa: Paul Gleason, Lee Harrell, and Keith Leaman, March 1968

content.description: This climb follows the first crack system to the right of the prominent Captain Hook chimney.  The climbing is hand jams and crux finger jams.  The easiest descent is to walk right to a tree and rappel 160' to the ground.
content.protection: standard rack

climbs.name: Insomnia
climbs.fa: Pat Callis & Larry Reynolds, June 1967,  FFA: Jim Erickson & Scott Stewart, March 1972

content.description:
Climb 25' up Buttress Chimney, the wide crack between the Sunshine Face & Buttress Of Cracks, and then enter a flared chimney (5.9) below a striking crack. Wiggle up the chimney and then launch directly into the crux, which can be jammed straight-on or lie-backed depending upon your hand size or preference. Higher the crack makes a jog left via a steep hand crack (5.10+) and finishes with some easy moves to a ledge with a bolted anchors.

Rappel (if slings are in place) or make an easy downclimb off the backside which leads to a notch where you can pick up a trail leading back to the base.
content.protection: Gear to 3 inches, bolted anchor
content.location:
This classic crack is found on the left end of the Buttress of Cracks, just left of the classic

Double Exposure

arete, and facing towards the Sunshine Face.

climbs.name: The Hernia
climbs.fa: Lee Harrell and S. Wood, August 1967

content.description:
Starts up a right-facing flake or directly up the face to reach a finger crack at the base of a large hollow-sounding flake. Continue past the flake and over a small overlap/roof to a flared section (small gear in the back) and finish up a flake system with incut face holds.

Not your typical 5.8 route as it offers a wide variety of climbing styles and is sure to hold your attention throughout.
content.protection: Gear to 3 inches (wires are handy), 2 bolt anchor/rap

climbs.name: Hernia - Direct Finish
climbs.fa: Ivan Couch & Mike Dent, 1969

content.description: Go straight up the face past a bolt where the regular route starts going right to the belay.
content.protection: 1 bolt, trad gear

climbs.name: Ham Sandwich
climbs.fa: Jim Hoagland & Dick Bird, 1980's

content.description:
Clip the first bolt of

Winter Solstice

and then move left to reach the start of a left-facing flake system, shared with Club Sandwich and Bacon Bits, which curves up and left to join

The Hernia

at it's roof. Finish up via Hernia and use that route's anchors.

Essentially a slightly harder, alternate start to The Hernia that offers some good climbing along thin flakes as you stop to wiggle in gear. Worth doing if you've done The Hernia and seek more of a challenge.
content.protection: 1 bolt (3/8"), gear to 3" including some thin stuff, bolted anchor/rap (100')
content.location: Located on the far right side of the Buttress of Cracks, just to the left of Arcy Farcy, the right-most bolted route here.

climbs.name: Frustration
climbs.fa: Pat Callis and Lee Harrell, March 1968

content.description: There is a crux jam move near the start, a 5.9 move 40 feet up, and and easy chimney above.  The quality of the climbing is so-so.
content.protection: Standard rack, 3 bolt anchor
content.location: This route follows the second crack system to the right of the Captain Hook chimney.

climbs.name: Double Trouble
climbs.fa: Matt Beebe December 2018

content.description: Climb the difficult beginning of The Pirate than traverse left to the first bolt of Double Exposure Direct and continue climbing Double Exposure to the top of the cliff. Â You can also TR the difficult part of the climb from the Pirate anchor and cut back to the Pirate once the climbing eases up and after passing the first two bolts of Double Exposure Direct.
content.protection: gear and bolts
content.location: Start at the Pirate. Finish on Double Exposure.

climbs.name: Double Exposure Direct
climbs.fa: FA: Tony Yaniro (TR) - 1978  FFA: Terry Ayers and Darrell Hensel - 1990

content.description:
This is a direct free start to the Double Exposure Arete. There are only two bolts before joining Double Exposure at the point where it comes onto the arete at the knobs, making this somewhat serious.

Start just down and right of the regular Double Exposure start. Hard moves lead around the corner to a second bolt. Pass the second bolt and continue on runout climbing until the Regular route is joined. Follow the regular route to the top.
content.protection: Bolts and gear up to 1".
content.location: Extreme left edge of the Buttress of Cracks.

climbs.name: Double Exposure
climbs.fa: John Long, 1975

content.description:
This spetacular route has a great location, climbing directly on the arete that forms the left hand edge of the Buttress of Cracks.

Start around the corner from

The Pirate

. A shoulder stand leads to two steep bolts of aid and then runout moves over to and up the arete (sling might work on a knob). Follow the arete to the top (10b), belaying at the

Insomnia

anchor. Great climbing with superb positions.
content.protection: Bolts, gear to 1".  Aid slings or runners for the aid.
content.location: Extreme left edge of the Buttress of Cracks.

climbs.name: Captain Hook
climbs.fa: Charlie Raymond and Larry Reynolds, October 1966

content.description: This prominent chimney is near the left end of the Buttress of Cracks. The first pitch (5.7) is a steep, well-protected chimney with a crux overhang at the top. The second pitch (5.6) follows another chimney directly above the belay ledge and is possible to combine with the first pitch with a 70+ meter rope. It finishes at a two bolt anchor near the top of the buttress, allowing you to scramble off or rappel.
content.protection: standard rack, with a few medium to large pieces

climbs.name: The Buccaneer
climbs.fa: unknown

content.description: This route is just to the left of the top of first pitch of Captain Hook and is a cleaner way finish. At the first belay look to the left 1 bolt protects a few face moves (crux) to the Pirate ledge. Rap 80 feet or go right to Swashbuckler 5.10d or straight up on Pieces of Eight 5.10d.
content.protection: 1 bolt med.wire stoppers or small cams.

climbs.name: Bocomaru
climbs.fa: Clark Jacobs and Bob Bolton, 1983

content.description:
Good rock, good climbing, thin technical moves.

From the extreme left end of the ledge make a move or two to stand up at the first bolt. The crux is encountered almost immediately, 11d edging/smearing on small steepish holds. Above, pass two more bolts, moving around the rib (11a) to the right after the last bolt. Somewhat runout climbing takes one to the top of the Buttress of Cracks.

Alternatively, it is possible to go left and up at the third bolt (10d), compliments of John Long. This is a more serious finish and may be loose enough to be unpleasant/scary.
content.protection: Bolts and a bit of gear for the top anchor.
content.location: The large ledge on the left hand side of East Buttress Gully.  One can also get there by doing a couple of moves up and right from the belay at the end of Captain Hook's first pitch.

climbs.name: Bluebeard
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines et al., June, 1989

content.description: This is a short, exciting face climb.  It is on a small formation just below The Pirate.  Scramble down and traverse in from the left.  Unprotected crux moves lead up to the first bolt.  A good spot (tough to arrange on the exposed starting ledge) would help you if you fell here.  The moves above are fun and well-protected.  The climb finishes along the trail by the base of The Pirate.
content.protection: Gear for the belay at the bottom and at the top.  I don't remember whether I was able to place any gear on the actual climb.

climbs.name: Bacon Bits (aka Razor Games)
climbs.fa: Russ Clune, October, 1987, First Lead: Kelly Vaught, Clark Jacobs and Rick Harlin, November 2000

content.description: This route is to the right of Hernia and the left of Winter Solstice.  About 20 feet to the first bolt, then small pieces in the expanding flake for pro before the second bolt.  Small edges--thus the name, Razor Games.
content.protection: 5 bolts plus small gear for the flake, 2 bolt/rap anchor shared with Hernia, Arcy Farcy, Winter Solstice.

climbs.name: Arcy Farcy Mantle
climbs.fa: John Long

content.description: 2nd pitch of Arcy Farcy, directly above rap bolts for the wall. One marginal bolt, blowing the mantle would be bad. Easy to TR off big tree on the ledge above.
content.protection: One bolt. You can rap the face by traversing left on ledge to bolts above Frustration.
content.location: Do P1 of Arcy Farcy then look for lone bolt, or climb gulley to right and traverse to rap bolts for Arcy Farcy/Winter Solstice, exposed but ok.

climbs.name: Arcy Farcy
climbs.fa: Mike Kaeser, Greg Bender, Phil Warrender & Jim Wilson, 1972

content.description: This is the right-most climb on the left side of the Buttress Of Cracks and climbs smooth face past three widely spaced bolts to a bolted anchor at the top. Rap off or downclimb the gully to the right (5.5).
content.protection: 3 bolts, bolted anchor/rap (100' rap)

climbs.name: Aqualung Direct
climbs.fa: Steve Mackay and Alan Vick, January 1973. FFA: Richard Harrison, Rob Muir, Tobin Sorenson, and Sibylle Hechtel, 1974"

content.description: Begin just left of the regular Aqualung start, and climb a thin crack with poor pro (11c R), followed by easier climbing (5.8) up thin cracks to join Aqualung at a small pine tree.
content.protection: Fixed RURPs were supposedly used for pro on the FFA.
